awd_titl_txt: CICI: RDP: SAMPRA: Scalable Analysis, Management, and Protection of Research Artifacts
awd_abstract_narration:
Current computing systems that support research on sensitive data, such as personally identifiable information, are frequently single-purpose and rely on ad-hoc approaches to data protection and management.  This project develops system called SAMPRA: Scalable Analysis, Management, and Protection of Research Artifacts.  SAMPRA's goal is to provide a compliant research computing platform that supports diverse, inter-disciplinary, collaborative research on protected data.  SAMPRA leverages modern virtualization technology to enable the decentralized management of protected computing enclaves that can be customized to the needs of each specific research project. In addition, the project trains researchers and students on best practices for managing and analyzing protected data, and technical staff on how to customize environments to the needs of individual research groups.

SAMPRA investigates multiple techniques to meet these goals, with the overall technical goal of understanding the technical and administrative tradeoffs between isolating and sharing protected research infrastructure services. First, SAMPRA systematically virtualizes hardware, software, and network resources to provide a flexible system architecture that supports research computing with varying analysis, management, and protection needs. SAMPRA also provides virtual data transfer nodes to interface protected environments with external data acquisition systems, with the goal of supporting modern data-intensive research projects using central institutional resources. The project develops exemplar computing, data analysis, and data management virtual environments, and integrating these with institutional systems for managing protected data. These exemplar systems are also the examples used in workshops that train researchers on the use of SAMPRA to support research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research on this project focused on creating new systems, software, processes, and workflows to effectively support management of sensitive research data, including both securing sensitive data to protect it from unintentional disclosure, and to allow sensitive data artifacts to be managed and shared appropriately.

Key project outcomes were:

  1. Creation and publication of new workflows for integrating support for management of secure research data across multiple university departments.
  2. Development of a system architecture for handling sensitive research data based on integrating virtual environments with data transfer nodes and data management systems.
  3. Deployment and security assessment of a prototype of this architecture, with a focus on the strengths and weaknesses of using technical controls vs. operational processes to mitigate potential data disclosure risks.
  4. Evaluation of the data management needs of multiple research data projects involving sensitive data, including research on forensic anthropology, clinical neurosciences, and electric power grid systems.
  5. Assessment of the usefulness of the prototype system architecture in supporting clinical neurosciences research, including during pandemic-related lockdowns.
  6. Deployment of the New Mexico Decedent Information Database, a deidentified database of medical investigation images for use in a wide range of forensic anthropology and related medical imaging research studies.
  7. Design and prototype implementation of a general virtual data transfer node architecture for automatically retrieving and deidentifying sensitive data for sharing using the Globus and iRODs technologies.
  8. Design of revised production workflows and architecture for deployment as a University-wide institutional research computing service.

Development of cross-cutting workflows to support sensitive research was a key research area throughout the project. Like most universities, the University of New Mexico has research computing expertise distributed across many departments and divisions, and integrating this expertise into a coherent process for support research is often difficult. This research project integrated expertise from UNM libraries, computer science, advanced research computing, IT information security, and IT platforms to develop a full workflow for supporting this research. These development of these workflows increased collaboration and effectiveness for support across campus, and while these workflows are still being revised based on project experience, they have been published to inform the research computing community of our experiences creating and deploying them.

The overall virtualization architecture was highly successful - it provided a flexible platform that allowed project personnel to examine a range of approaches for data handling in the system. In addition, it allowed limited administrative access for a wider range of personnel than would have been feasible on non-virtualized systems. Finally, it also provided a platform for the development of more sophisticated data sharing services. UNM is currently in the process of converting the prototype system on which this research was conducted into an institutional production system.

One key result of assessing this platform was an examination of the tradeoffs between technical (i.e. software/hardware) and operational (i.e. process) security measures when supporting modern research. While key technical controls (e.g. encryption, two-factor authentication) are necessary, studies of the needs of diverse research areas pointed to the need to prefer operational controls when appropriate. That is because these processes are often easier to customize to better support the needs of research than technical controls fixed in software or hardware setups.

The project also resulted in the deployment of new research data for use by researchers worldwide. The New Mexico Decedent Information Database, which served as an initial study example and was deployed using data management tools developed as part of this project has supported research by 573 researchers from 46 countries. In addition, these data management tools were also used to deidentify medical imaging data in support of COVID-19 research on the suitability of CT imaging to identify COVID-19 causes of death.

Toward the end of the project, research examined other architectures for handling data management, particularly those based that dynamically deidentified or redacted data to better handle changing or streaming data sets. In particular, the project successfully demonstrated that the combination of Globus and iRODs could successfully dynamically deidentify remote data sources, providing a foundation for creating a web of data lakes for sharing sensitive research data. In addition, the project identified additional opportunities for research in this direction, particularly the need for research on handling sensitive streaming data.
